column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=The development of flow processes has gained tremendous interest in recent years in organic chemistry due to numerous advantages of such types of processes over classic batch approaches .
#Text=In addition to higher efficiency and safety advantages , the ability to ensure constant product quality has turned out to be a major driving force for the development of flow processes .

#Text=In particular , for active pharmaceutical ingredients ( APIs ) , this aspect is important , as the FDA along with the EPA , as the respective institutions in United States and Europe for approval of medicines , added aspects of continuous manufacturing to their guidelines , whereas for a long time the focus of flow processes was on “ classic ” chemical processes with , for example , hazardous and thermally labile substances and chemocatalytic reactions .
#Text=Recently , biocatalysis in flow processes has become an emerging field with an increasing number of examples .

#Text=An enzymatic reaction of particular interest for an application in flow mode due to its matured technology level is asymmetric ketone reduction , having a proven track record underlined by many successful examples demonstrated in the past for the batch mode .
#Text=Recently , significant process in the biocatalytic reductive synthesis of alcohols starting from ketones , as well as syntheses by non-enzymatic means , have been reported .
#Text=In recent years , an increasing number of examples of biocatalysis in flow processes have been reported .
#Text=Although only being studied to a minor extent , some examples of ketone reductions with an alcohol dehydrogenase ( ADH ) in flow processes have been described .

#Text=For example , Wandrey ’s and Liese ’s groups studied in detail the application of enzyme membrane reactors for enzymatic ketone reduction in a continuously running mode , and packed bed reactor setups were described by further groups using carrier-bound ADH from Lactobacillus brevis ( LB-ADH ) in combination with a mobile aqueous phase , or magnetic nanoparticle-bound ADH .
#Text=In addition , Buehler et al. investigated intensively the use of ADH in aqueous/organic segmented flow systems .
#Text=It was shown that emulsion formation could be eliminated , and enzymatic mass transfer-limited reactions can be enhanced .
#Text=Furthermore , different means of stabilization of this reaction system were investigated .
#Text=Very recently , our group published an improved downstream process by means of such a segmented flow process , illustrated using two different ADHs and substrates .
#Text=In continuous processes using packed bed reactors ( PBR ) , catalyst immobilization is a prerequisite .
#Text=Also , downstream processes benefit from immobilization , as separation of the reaction mixture from the catalyst is easier , and the catalyst reusability is improved .
#Text=Moreover , both , operational , as well as storage stability of the catalyst can potentially be significantly increased .

#Text=However , often a significant loss of enzymatic activity during the immobilization process represents a drawback , and the reproducible production of immobilized catalyst may be a further challenge .

#Text=Numerous techniques have been developed over the past years , which can be classified in the following three major methods : ( a ) binding to a solid support ( carrier ) , ( b ) entrapment ( encapsulation ) in polymer networks , or ( c ) cross-linking in the form of cross-linked enzyme aggregates ( CLEAs ) or cross-linked enzyme crystals ( CLECs ) .
#Text=Recently , much progress in the field of enzyme immobilization has been made .
#Text=In this work , the option of entrapment of enzymes in polymer networks has been chosen .
#Text=Often for this purpose , organic polymers containing cavities , sol-gel-processed particles , or membranes are used .
#Text=A special case is the use of superabsorbent polymers to immobilize the entire aqueous phase. .
#Text=In this case , the enzyme is immobilized in its native aqueous environment , whereby undesired interactions of protein moieties with the support can be prevented .
#Text=Recently , Gröger et al. applied a method of immobilizing ADHs with superabsorber efficiently for the synthesis of diols in enantiomerically pure form .
#Text=In this example , the immobilized ADH from Rhodococcus sp. was used in organic solvents without a major loss in activity .
#Text=Advantages of this method is the low cost , the very fast immobilization procedure ( <30 min ) , and the excellent catalyst reusability .

#Text=Challenging , in particular with respect to an application in a fixed bed reactor , might be the gel-like consistency of the hydrogel and mass transfer limitations through phase interfaces in general .
#Text=The absorbent polymer consists of cross-linked polyacrylic acid , which was partially neutralized .
#Text=Proteins can be embedded in this polymer matrix and can be bound , for example , by ionic interactions of its acid moieties to ionic amino acid residues of the protein ( see
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=A ) .
#Text=Also , hydrogen bridges from non-ionic protein residues with superabsorber functionalities (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=B ) or entrapment of enzyme in superabsorber-bound water residues (
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=C ) can be a possible mode of interaction .

#Text=An ( R )-enantioselective ADH from Lactobacillus brevis ( LB-ADH ) has been shown to be a versatile catalyst for the reduction of a variety of ketones , ranging from aliphatic ketones to benzylic or propargylic ketones .
#Text=It can be used as an isolated enzyme or as a whole-cell catalyst .
#Text=In particular , its tolerance towards organic solvents is outstanding .
#Text=The stability depends on several factors , such as the nature of the buffer or solvent additives .
#Text=In this contribution , the application of a superabsorber-immobilized ADH from L. brevis for an enzymatic reduction of acetophenone ( 1 ) in a flow process is described .
